citation.article-title: Kerstersia gyiorum gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel Alcaligenes faecalis-like organism isolated from human clinical samples, and reclassification of Alcaligenes denitrificans Rüger and Tan 1983 as Achromobacter denitrificans comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Kerstersia (Kers.ters′i.a. N.L. fem. n. Kerstersia in honour of K. Kersters, an eminent Belgian microbiologist, for his contributions to polyphasic taxonomy and to the introduction of computerized protein gel electrophoresis).
Gram-negative, small (1–2 μm long), coccoid cells that occur as single units, in pairs or in short chains.
On nutrient agar, colonies are flat or slightly convex with smooth margins with a colour ranging from white to light brown.
Catalase activity, but not oxidase, urease or β-galactosidase activity, is observed.
Additional biochemical characteristics are given above (see Results).
MIC values for a number of antibiotics are shown in Supplementary Table B in IJSEM Online.
The following fatty acid components are present: 14 : 0, 14 : 0 2-OH, 16 : 0, 17 : 0 cyclo, 18 : 0, 18 : 1ω7c, 19 : 0 cyclo ω8c, summed feature 2 and summed feature 3.
Strains of this genus have been isolated from various human clinical samples.
The type species is Kerstersia gyiorum.
